Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Thoracic Drainage Strategies in Lung Cancer Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised

Participants.evidence: patients aged 18-75 undergoing lung cancer surgery, with no prior thoracic surgery. Conducted at a tertiary care hospital

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received digital drainage systems, while the control group received analogue systems

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the effectiveness of different thoracic drainage strategies following lung cancer surgery

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was drainage duration, measured over a 30-day postoperative period

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed using sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the intervention, blinding was not feasible

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the digital drainage system group and 100 to the analogue drainage system group

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the intention-to-treat analysis, 98 participants in the digital group and 97 in the analogue group were analysed

Result_Outcome.evidence: The digital group had a significantly shorter drainage duration (mean difference = 1.5 days, 95% CI 0.8 to 2.2; p = 0.001)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were reported in 3% of the digital group and 1% of the analogue group, with mild severity

Funding.evidence: This trial was funded by the National Institutes of Health
